   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Respiratory distress on [**7-13**] attributed to his
   respiratory/lactic acidosis with LLL PNA, possible infiltrative
   lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, in the setting of
   aggressive fluid resuscitation. Patient also has a question of a
   history of COPD with significant smoking history (50+ pack years)
   -Switched from AC mode to pressure support [**5-19**] and well tolerated this
   morning. Given that and ABG as well as patient being more alert on
   increased sedation, work toward weaning the vent today.
   -sedation with fentanyl/midazolam, continue until ready to wean vent.
   -Continue antibiotics for PNA: CTX + Cipro
   -Repeat CXR for ETT placement
   -Repeat ABG today after changing vent settings.
   -f/u blood and sputum cx
   Cardiovascular: Persistent tachycardia to 120s for first couple days of
   admission on telemetry and EKG despite significant volume
   resuscitation. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart
   failure. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but this was d/c
ed after an
   episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing on [**7-13**]
   as well as pressors. Cardiac enzymes not concerning for MI, slight
   elevation in troponin likely secondary to ARF.
   -Follow EKGs
   -Follow cardiology recs if they still would like to follow the patient
   -Avoid beta-blockers
   -Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of [**10-26**] to protect his kidneys.
   -If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be
   phenylephrine.
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. All
   trending down with IVF and single dose of rasbiricase. CT c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process and patient also with
   concerning thickening in stomach, ureters, and possible mass at bottom
   of thoracic spine per MRI.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs (bone marrow biopsy pending, current thinking is ALL
   versus Burkitt
s. challenging review in setting of steroid
   administration) and discuss chemotherapy plans

   Renal/FEN: Creatinine went from 0.6 at admission to max of 1.6,

   acid levels to 12 range.  Patient
s initial presentation was also

   urothelial thickening and prostate may also be enlarged in the setting
   of acromegaly.

   Endocrine: Per OSH records, he had an MRI/MRA head [**7-11**] which revealed
   a 19 x30x 15mm pituitary macroadenoma which had some invasion of left
   cavernous sinus. Acromegaly suspected and could help explain appearance

   urinary retention. Endocrinology consult called and patient has had

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and possible lymphoma. He presented with respiratory distress, leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. He also has a history of Bell's palsy and urinary retention. The patient has been treated with antibiotics for pneumonia and has been receiving hydration and diuretics to manage his respiratory and cardiac status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory distress and lactic acidosis put him at risk for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his respiratory status and adjustments to his ventilator settings are necessary to prevent further deterioration.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's tachycardia and elevated troponin levels suggest cardiac stress. Further cardiac evaluation is necessary to rule out myocardial infarction or other cardiac complications.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and ARF put him at risk for further renal damage. Close monitoring of his renal function and adjustment of his fluid and electrolyte management are necessary to prevent further decline.
4. Infections: The patient's pneumonia and possible lymphoma put him at risk for further infections. Close monitoring of his temperature and white blood cell count is necessary to detect any signs of infection.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient's Bell's palsy and possible infiltration of his cranial nerves put him at risk for further neurological complications. Close monitoring of his neurological status and adjustments to his pain management plan are necessary to prevent further deterioration.
6. Endocrine Complications: The patient's acromegaly and possible infiltration of his pituitary gland put him at risk for endocrine complications. Close monitoring of his hormone levels and adjustment of his hormone replacement therapy are necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's possible infiltration of his gastrointestinal tract put him at risk for gastrointestinal complications. Close monitoring of his bowel movements and adjustment of his pain management plan are necessary to prevent further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilator settings as necessary to prevent further respiratory failure.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as necessary to prevent further cardiac complications.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid and electrolyte management as necessary to prevent further decline.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's temperature and white blood cell count to detect any signs of infection.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his pain management plan as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hormone levels and adjust his hormone replacement therapy as necessary to prevent further complications.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's bowel movements and adjust his pain management plan as necessary to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male who is critically ill in the ICU due to tumor lysis syndrome, respiratory distress, and pneumonia. He has a complex medical history, including possible diagnoses of acromegaly and lymphoma.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. His ABG results show a pH of 7.39, PaO2 of 266, and PaCO2 of 48. He has mild rhonchi and wheezing at the bases of his lungs.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has persistent tachycardia and has required pressors in the past. His cardiac enzymes are slightly elevated, but not concerning for myocardial infarction.
* Hematological: The patient has significant anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia. His LDH is elevated, and he has hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is receiving fluid resuscitation. His creatinine has decreased from 1.6 to 0.8, but he remains at risk for further kidney damage.
* Endocrine: The patient has acromegaly, which is suspected to be contributing to his cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention.
* Neurological: The patient has diffuse nerve root enhancement on MRI and epidural signal changes at T9, T12, and L2, which may be related to his underlying malignancy.
* Infectious: The patient has pneumonia and is receiving antibiotics. He also has a question of STI orchitis and may require an HIV test.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and pneumonia put him at risk for respiratory failure.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's persistent tachycardia and history of bradycardia put him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's AKI and ongoing fluid resuscitation put him at risk for further kidney damage and potential renal failure.
* Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and ongoing antibiotic use put him at risk for developing new infections.
* Neurological deterioration: The patient's underlying malignancy and potential infiltrative process may lead to further neurological deterioration.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation to manage his respiratory distress.
* Monitor his cardiac status and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
* Continue fluid resuscitation and monitor his renal function.
* Perform further workup to determine the cause of his lymphoma and develop a treatment plan.
* Monitor his neurological status and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
* Consider HIV testing and treatment if necessary.
* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia and consider adding additional antibiotics if necessary.
* Monitor his blood glucose levels and adjust his medication regimen as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who is intubated and mechanically ventilated due to respiratory failure. The patient's condition is multifactorial, with possible underlying pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient's fever is persistent, and imaging studies have been unrevealing. Cultures are pending, and the patient is receiving empiric antimicrobial therapy.

The patient's hemodynamic status is concerning, with hypotension that may be related to sepsis and component of hypovolemia. The patient's fluid status is also a concern, and the need to further assess intravascular status is emphasized. The patient's acute renal failure is improving following resuscitation, and the etiology is attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), possible tumor lysis syndrome, bilateral obstruction, and drug effect.

The patient's electrolyte levels are being closely monitored, and the patient is receiving treatment for tumor lysis syndrome with Rasburicase and Allopurinol. The patient's bone marrow results are pending, and the oncology team is considering a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The patient's nutritional support is being managed, and the patient is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) if no plans for procedures are in place. The patient's glycemic control is being monitored, and the patient is receiving stress ulcer prophylaxis with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).

The patient's lines and prophylaxis are being managed, with a focus on preventing deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's code status is full code, and the patient is being managed in the intensive care unit (ICU). The patient's total time spent in the ICU is 35 minutes.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's persistent fever and unrevealing imaging studies suggest the possibility of pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension and fever suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute renal failure is a concern, and further evaluation is needed to determine the etiology and prevent further kidney damage.
4. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's elevated uric acid levels and bone marrow results pending suggest the possibility of tumor lysis syndrome, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and kidney damage.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia: The patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and sepsis.
6. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's immobility and prolonged hospitalization increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, suspected pneumonia, and underlying COPD. The patient remains intubated and mechanically ventilated, with improved oxygenation and pH levels. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate of 102 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 141/76 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC count: 8.9-6.1 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 28.2-23.6%
* Plt: 48 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 1.5-0.8 mg/dL
* TCO2: 25-30 mmHg
* Glucose: 138-159 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 12.3/24.6/1.0, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 138/3/0.02, ALT/AST: 18/31, Alk Phos/T Bili: 104/0.3, Differential-Neuts: 66.0% Band: 2.0%, Lymph: 16.0%, Mono: 8.0%, Eos: 1.0%, Lactic Acid: 3.0 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.9 g/dL, LDH: 5301 IU/L, Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.9 mg/dL, PO4: 4.1 mg/dL

The patient's fluid analysis shows:

* Uric acid: 7.2-6.5 mg/dL

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Respiratory failure: multifactorial, suspect pneumonia LLL (possible aspiration), diffuse bronchovascular disease with lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying COPD. Monitor ABG, maintain pH 7.35-7.40, pO2 >60 mmHg. Continue antimicrobials.
* Fevers: persistent, possible underlying systemic process (such as symptoms from maligancy) or infection (ex. Pneumonia). Unrevealing imaging. Cultures pending. Monitor fevers, use coolig blanket. Continue empiric antimicrobials (Vanco, ceftriaxone, Ciprofloxicin)
* Hypotension: concern for sepsis and component of hypovolemia. No evidence for adrenal insufficiency. Improved, and now off vasopressors. Maintain CVP 10-12 cm H2O.
* Fluids: need to further assess intravascular status. Require iv fluid bolus to maintain. Follow CVP 10-12 cm H2O.
* Acute renal failure: improving following resuscitation. Attributed to ATN, possible tumor lysis syndrome, bilateral obstruction, drug effect. Renal dose all medications.
* Tumor lysis syndrome: unclear etiology. Continue Rasburicase, Allopurinol. Trend electrolytes q8 hrs. Oncology preliminary impression favors ALL/AML bone marrow results pending. Continue dexamethasone.
* Acromegally: reportedly with evidence for Pituitary adenoma. Evaluation in progress.
* Nutritional support: initiate TF if no plans for procedures.

The patient's ICU care includes:

* Nutrition: initiate TF if no plans for procedures.
* Glycemic control: maintain blood glucose levels within normal range.
* Lines: 18 Gauge, Multi Lumen, and Arterial Line.
* Prophylaxis: DVT (boots), stress ulcer (PPI), and VAP (HOB elevation, mouth care).

The patient's code status is full code, and their disposition is ICU. The patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal systems.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and
   increased difficulty breathing. Being treated for LLL PNA, suspicion
   for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Repeat CXR this afternoon
   -Get better COPD history from friend
   -Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
   -Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator
   settings
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure.
   -Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**].
   -EKG
   -Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow
   cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspiction for an
   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process,  thickening in stomach, ureters.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) Q12H
   -continue allopurinol
   -EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high
   given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
   -continue hydration
   -f/u stool guaiac
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now.
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed.
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain intial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, and free IGF-1 level requested by endocrine was not
   possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and PTH were both normal, eliminating
   suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine consult
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.  Neurosurgery following. Patient already on
   dexamethasone for malignancy treatment.
   -f/u with neurosurgery regarding T-spine mass and MRI of lumbar spine
   as well as repeat imaging of pituitary macroadenoma (surgery likely the
   definitive treatment)
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   -continue acyclovir
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]).

   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and possible lymphoma. He presented with respiratory distress, leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia. The patient has a history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention.

Current Status:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. He has a mild wheezing on the left with mild basilar crackles.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is tachycardic, with a heart rate of 109-122 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 115/57 mmHg.
* Hematological: The patient has a white blood cell count of 6.1 x 10^9/L and a platelet count of 157 x 10^9/L.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury, which is resolving.
* Endocrine: The patient has a new diagnosis of acromegaly, with a pituitary macroadenoma on MRI/MRA.
* Neurological: The patient has a history of cranial nerve palsies and urinary retention, which may be related to his acromegaly.
* Infectious Disease: The patient has a hospital-acquired pneumonia, being treated with vancomycin and ceftriaxone.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has a history of urinary retention and tender scrotal swelling, which may be related to an epididymitis/orchitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Respiratory: Pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
* Cardiovascular: Hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.
* Hematological: Bleeding, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.
* Renal: Acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalances.
* Endocrine: Hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia, and adrenal insufficiency.
* Neurological: Seizures, stroke, and cognitive impairment.
* Infectious Disease: Sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome.
* Gastrointestinal: Gastrointestinal bleeding, constipation, and malnutrition.

Recommendations:

* Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation with fentanyl and midazolam.
* Repeat CXR and get better COPD history from friend.
* Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of 10-26 mmHg.
* Avoid beta blockers given history of hypotension on metoprolol.
* Continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phosphorus, calcium) every 12 hours.
* Continue allopurinol and hydration.
* Monitor BUN and Cr levels.
* Avoid IV contrast and nephrotoxic medications.
* Consider sending PCR if suspicion is high given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP.
* Continue acyclovir and consider sending HIV test when patient is alert and able to consent.
* Monitor UOP and Foley in place.
* Avoid NSAIDs and continue pain control with fentanyl.

   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of

   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original

s Palsy and urinary retention.

   By system:
   Respiratory: Respiratory distress on [**7-13**] attributed to his
   respiratory/lactic acidosis with LLL PNA, possible infiltrative
   lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, in the setting of
   aggressive fluid resuscitation. Patient also has a question of a
   history of COPD with significant smoking history (50+ pack years)
   -Advance ETT 1cm more because cuff appears to be above thoracic inlet
   -Switched from AC mode to pressure support [**5-19**] and well tolerated this
   morning. Given that and ABG as well as patient being more alert on
   increased sedation, work toward weaning the vent today.

   failure. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but this was d/c
ed after an
   episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing on [**7-13**]

   -If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be

   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. All

   -Advance ETT 1cm more because cuff appears to be above thoracic inlet

ed after an

   -Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of [**10-26**] to protect his kidneys.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a complex medical condition. The patient's chief complaints include tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for acromegaly and possible lymphoma, and respiratory distress leading to intubation and hypotensive bradycardia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F)
* Heart rate: 109 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 115/57 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Heart rhythm: Sinus tachycardia

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 6.1 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 23.9%
* Plt: 157 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.8 mg/dL
* TCO2: 30 mmHg
* Glucose: 159 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 3.9 mmol/L
* LDH: 3684 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.6 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.6 mg/dL
* PO4: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's current medications include:

* Midazolam (Versed): 8 mg/hour
* Fentanyl (Concentrate): 350 mcg/hour
* Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis): 10,000 units/hour
* Famotidine (Pepcid): 20 mg/hour
* Ciprofloxacin: 500 mg every 12 hours
* Vancomycin: 1 g every 12 hours
* Ceftriaxone: 2 g every 12 hours

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continue antibiotics for pneumonia
* Repeat CXR for ETT placement
* Repeat ABG today after changing vent settings
* Follow EKGs
* Follow cardiology recs if they still want to follow the patient
* Avoid beta-blockers
* Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of 10-12 mmHg to protect the kidneys
* If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be phenylephrine
* Continue hydration
* Guaiac stools (Hct trending down since admission)
* Monitor BUN and Cr
* Continue fluids to CVP 10-12
* Avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds until Cr stabilized
* Replete electrolytes as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Renal failure
* Infections (e.g. pneumonia, urinary tract infection)
* Malignancy progression
* Neurological complications (e.g. Bell's palsy, neuropathy)
* Endocrine complications (e.g. hypercalcemia, hypoglycemia)
* Metabolic complications (e.g. lactic acidosis, hyperkalemia)

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and treatment response to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical history, including tumor lysis syndrome, acromegaly, and possible lymphoma. He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress, pneumonia, and lactic acidosis.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status is improving, and he is tolerating pressure support mode.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has persistent tachycardia, which is being monitored closely. His cardiac enzymes are slightly elevated, but not concerning for myocardial infarction. He is being followed by cardiology and is on pressors as needed.
* Hematology/Oncology: The patient has significant laboratory abnormalities, including hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia. He is being treated with rasburicase and allopurinol, and his laboratory values are trending down. He is also being worked up for a possible diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or Burkitt lymphoma.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) due to tumor lysis syndrome, and his creatinine is elevated. He is being monitored closely for electrolyte abnormalities and is receiving hydration.
* Endocrine: The patient has acromegaly, which is suspected to be causing his cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention.
* Neuro: The patient has diffuse nerve root enhancement of the lumbar spine and epidural signal changes at T9, T12, and L2, which are likely related to his underlying malignancy. He is being followed by neurosurgery.
* Infectious Disease: The patient has a hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and is being treated with vancomycin and ceftriaxone.
* GU: The patient has urinary retention, which is being treated with a Foley catheter. He also has tender scrotal swelling and epididymitis/orchitis, which is being monitored closely.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, but his respiratory status is still unstable.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has persistent tachycardia and may be at risk for cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient has AKI and is at risk for further kidney damage.
* Infection: The patient has a HAP and is at risk for further infection.
* Neurological complications: The patient has diffuse nerve root enhancement and epidural signal changes, which may lead to neurological deficits.
* Endocrine complications: The patient has acromegaly, which may lead to further complications, such as hypertrophic arthropathy and cranial nerve palsies.

Based on the patient's complex medical history and current status, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management to prevent and address potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical history, including tumor lysis syndrome, acromegaly, and possible lymphoma. He was admitted to the ICU due to respiratory distress, hypotensive bradycardia, and lactic acidosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He was extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and increased difficulty breathing. He is being treated for LLL PNA, and a suspicion of infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process is based on chest CT findings.
* Cardiovascular: He is tachycardic, with a heart rate of 109-122 bpm, and has a normal EF and no evidence of heart failure on TTE.
* Heme-Onc: His labs at admission showed significantly elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia, consistent with tumor lysis syndrome. All trended down and now are normal. He received two doses of rasburicase and is now on allopurinol.
* Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving, with creatinine back at baseline of 0.5 mg/dL.
* Endocrine: He has a new diagnosis of acromegaly, with a pituitary macroadenoma (presumptive source) on MRI/MRA. This may explain his initial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention.
* Neuro: He has a history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention, and his MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for possible masses. He is already on dexamethasone for malignancy treatment.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and sedation.
2. Cardiovascular instability: His tachycardia and hypotensive bradycardia episodes may recur, and he may require further cardiovascular monitoring and treatment.
3. Renal failure: Although his ARF seems to be resolving, he may still require close monitoring of his renal function and electrolyte levels.
4. Endocrine instability: His acromegaly diagnosis may lead to further endocrine instability, and he may require ongoing endocrine monitoring and treatment.
5. Neurological complications: His history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention may indicate potential neurological complications, and he may require ongoing neurological monitoring and treatment.
6. Infection: He is at risk of developing hospital-acquired pneumonia, and his sputum and blood cultures are pending.
7. Bleeding complications: His thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding complications, and he may require close monitoring of his platelet count and bleeding risk.

Based on this information, I recommend the following:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and sedation to manage his respiratory status.
2. Monitor his cardiovascular status closely, including his heart rate, blood pressure, and electrolyte levels.
3. Continue to trend his renal function and electrolyte levels, and monitor for any signs of renal failure.
4. Monitor his endocrine status closely, including his thyroid function and glucose levels.
5. Monitor his neurological status closely, including his cranial nerve function and lower extremity sensation/motor function.
6. Continue to monitor his infection risk and treat any suspected infections promptly.
7. Monitor his bleeding risk and platelet count closely, and treat any bleeding complications promptly.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential medical complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who has undergone invasive ventilation and has been extubated and reintubated due to tachypnea and increased work of breathing. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management medications.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 109 bpm, and blood pressure of 115/57 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is compromised, with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 99%. The patient's oxygen saturation is within normal limits, but the patient is requiring supplemental oxygen.

The patient's laboratory results indicate a white blood cell count of 6.1 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 157 K/uL. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 31 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 18 IU/L. The patient's blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are within normal limits.

The patient's fluid status is stable, with a total fluid intake of 3,398 mL and a total fluid output of 2,540 mL. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with a sodium level of 140 mmol/L, potassium level of 4.3 mmol/L, and chloride level of 106 mmol/L.

The patient's medical history is significant for a recent diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, and the patient is receiving treatment for this condition. The patient's family history is significant for a history of cancer in a first-degree relative.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and the patient may require further respiratory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and liver enzymes may indicate the presence of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Bleeding complications: The patient's platelet count is low, and the patient may be at risk for bleeding complications.
4. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and recent diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia may make the patient susceptible to infection.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiac stress, which can lead to cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or heart failure.

Based on the patient's condition, further monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat potential complications. The patient's medical team should continue to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and fluid status to ensure that the patient's condition is stable and improving.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Respiratory distress on [**7-13**] attributed to his
   respiratory/lactic acidosis with LLL PNA, possible infiltrative
   lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, in the setting of
   aggressive fluid resuscitation. Patient also has a question of a
   history of COPD with significant smoking history (50+ pack years)
   -Advance ETT 1cm more because cuff appears to be above thoracic inlet
   -Switched from AC mode to pressure support [**5-19**] and well tolerated this
   morning. Given that and ABG as well as patient being more alert on
   increased sedation, work toward weaning the vent today.
   -sedation with fentanyl/midazolam, continue until ready to wean vent.
   -Continue antibiotics for PNA: CTX + Cipro
   -Repeat CXR for ETT placement
   -Repeat ABG today after changing vent settings.
   -f/u blood and sputum cx
   Cardiovascular: Persistent tachycardia to 120s for first couple days of
   admission on telemetry and EKG despite significant volume
   resuscitation. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart
   failure. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but this was d/c
ed after an
   episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing on [**7-13**]
   as well as pressors. Cardiac enzymes not concerning for MI, slight
   elevation in troponin likely secondary to ARF.
   -Follow EKGs
   -Follow cardiology recs if they still would like to follow the patient
   -Avoid beta-blockers
   -Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of [**10-26**] to protect his kidneys.
   -If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be
   phenylephrine.
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. All
   trending down with IVF and single dose of rasbiricase. CT c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process and patient also with
   concerning thickening in stomach, ureters, and possible mass at bottom
   of thoracic spine per MRI.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs (bone marrow biopsy pending, current thinking is ALL
   versus Burkitt
s. challenging review in setting of steroid
   administration) and discuss chemotherapy plans
   -trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) Q8H
   -start allopurinol given normalized Cr
   -repeat dose of rasbiracase 6mg x 1
   -EBV results
   -SPEP results
   -continue hydration
   -guaiac stools (Hct trending down since admission)
   Renal/FEN: Creatinine went from 0.6 at admission to max of 1.6,
   currently 0.8. ARF was attributed to ATN in the setting of high uric
   acid levels to 12 range.  Patient
s initial presentation was also
   urinary retention. U/S at OSH was reportedly normal. CT shows
   urothelial thickening and prostate may also be enlarged in the setting
   of acromegaly.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds until Cr stabilized
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed.
   Endocrine: Per OSH records, he had an MRI/MRA head [**7-11**] which revealed
   a 19 x30x 15mm pituitary macroadenoma which had some invasion of left
   cavernous sinus. Acromegaly suspected and could help explain appearance
   and intial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and
   urinary retention. Endocrinology consult called and patient has had
   normal TSH, low testosterone, LH elevated, slightly high cortisol
   levels. Prolactin is normal. PTH is normal. High [**Hospital1 **] at 11.2 and IGF was
   188.
   - f/u endocrine recs  (do they still want the following labs: free
   IGF-1(lab can instruct how to do this), IGFBP, repeat [**Hospital1 **], possible OGTT
   with [**Hospital1 **] levels 2hrs post 75g load, pituitary MRI, Vit D labs, UPEP
   - call for full opthalmology consult once alert and awake for thorough
   visual field tests
   -When stabilized, consider repeat Ca and PTH drawn at same time (PTH
   was normal in setting of high Ca)
   Neuro: MRI T-spine done and showed no overt compressions, but diffuse
   nerve root enhancement of lumbar spine and epidural signal changes at
   T9, T12, L2. Most likely from his overall infiltrative
   process/malignancy. Thoracic epidural enhancement on MRA, MRI
   concerning for possible masses.  Neurosurgery team is  following.
   Patient already on dexamethasone for malignancy treatment. No reported
   incontinence, only retention of urine but may be due to enlarged
   prostate from acromegaly vs additional obstruction at the level of
   ureter as imaging noted thickening of urothelial linings ( likely also
   related to underlying malignancy). Patient also initially presented
   with a Bell
s palsy, possibly related to acromegaly.
   -f/u with neurosurgery regarding T-spine mass and MRI of lumbar spine
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII
   -continue acyclovir
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc and CTX.
   Patient also on Cipro for question of STI orchitis.
   -consider HIV test in setting of possible aggressive lymphoma
   -f/u EBV PCR
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -d/c cipro
   -continue vanc and CTX for hospital-acquired PNA
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to
   enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT.
   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   Hcg and AFP negative.
   -Foley in place
   -Closely monitor UOP given recent h/o retention.
   MSK: Patient complained of diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly, possible infiltrative
   process.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  Tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:

   Disposition: [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] for now, pending above assessments and additional
   workup for malignancy

   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Respiratory distress on [**7-13**] attributed to his
   respiratory/lactic acidosis with LLL PNA, possible infiltrative
   lymphangitic malignant process in both lungs, in the setting of
   aggressive fluid resuscitation. Patient also has a question of a
   history of COPD with significant smoking history (50+ pack years)
   -Advance ETT 1cm more because cuff appears to be above thoracic inlet
   -Switched from AC mode to pressure support [**5-19**] and well tolerated this
   morning. Given that and ABG as well as patient being more alert on
   increased sedation, work toward weaning the vent today.
   -sedation with fentanyl/midazolam, continue until ready to wean vent.
   -Continue antibiotics for PNA: CTX + Cipro
   -Repeat CXR for ETT placement
   -Repeat ABG today after changing vent settings.
   -f/u blood and sputum cx
   Cardiovascular: Persistent tachycardia to 120s for first couple days of
   admission on telemetry and EKG despite significant volume
   resuscitation. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart
   failure. Cardiology recommended metoprolol but this was d/c
ed after an
   episode of serious bradycardia requiring transcutaneous pacing on [**7-13**]
   as well as pressors. Cardiac enzymes not concerning for MI, slight
   elevation in troponin likely secondary to ARF.
   -Follow EKGs
   -Follow cardiology recs if they still would like to follow the patient
   -Avoid beta-blockers
   -Monitor CVP with fluids to a goal of [**10-26**] to protect his kidneys.
   -If becomes hypotensive and tachycardic, first choice pressor would be
   phenylephrine.
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. All
   trending down with IVF and single dose of rasbiricase. CT c/w
   lymphangitic spread of diffuse malignant process and patient also with
   concerning thickening in stomach, ureters, and possible mass at bottom
   of thoracic spine per MRI.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs (bone marrow biopsy pending, current thinking is ALL

s. challenging review in setting of steroid

s initial presentation was also

   of acromegaly.
   -monitor BUN and Cr

   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds until Cr stabilized
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed.
   Endocrine: Per OSH records, he had an MRI/MRA head [**7-11**] which revealed
   a 19 x30x 15mm pituitary macroadenoma which had some invasion of left
   cavernous sinus. Acromegaly suspected and could help explain appearance
   and intial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and
   urinary retention. Endocrinology consult called and patient has had
   normal TSH, low testosterone, LH elevated, slightly high cortisol
   levels. Prolactin is normal. PTH is normal. High [**Hospital1 **] at 11.2 and IGF was
   188.
   - f/u endocrine recs  (do they still want the following labs: free
   IGF-1(lab can instruct how to do this), IGFBP, repeat [**Hospital1 **], possible OGTT

   was normal in setting of high Ca)
   Neuro: MRI T-spine done and showed no overt compressions, but diffuse
   nerve root enhancement of lumbar spine and epidural signal changes at
   T9, T12, L2. Most likely from his overall infiltrative
   process/malignancy. Thoracic epidural enhancement on MRA, MRI
   concerning for possible masses.  Neurosurgery team is  following.
   Patient already on dexamethasone for malignancy treatment. No reported
   incontinence, only retention of urine but may be due to enlarged
   prostate from acromegaly vs additional obstruction at the level of
   ureter as imaging noted thickening of urothelial linings ( likely also
   related to underlying malignancy). Patient also initially presented
   with a Bell
s palsy, possibly related to acromegaly.
   -f/u with neurosurgery regarding T-spine mass and MRI of lumbar spine
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial

s V and VII

   Patient also on Cipro for question of STI orchitis.

   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -d/c cipro
   -continue vanc and CTX for hospital-acquired PNA
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to
   enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT.
   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   Hcg and AFP negative.

   MSK: Patient complained of diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly, possible infiltrative

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male who presented with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for acromegaly and possible lymphoma. He was intubated due to respiratory distress and has a history of pneumonia, respiratory/lactic acidosis, and hypotensive bradycardia. The patient has a significant smoking history and a history of COPD.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 650 mL and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His ABG results show a pH of 7.37, PCO2 of 48 mmHg, and PO2 of 109 mmHg.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has persistent tachycardia, and his cardiac enzymes are slightly elevated. He has a history of hypotensive bradycardia and was treated with transcutaneous pacing and pressors.
* Heme-Onc: The patient has elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia. He is being treated with rasburicase and allopurinol.
* Renal/FEN: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) attributed to ATN and is being treated with fluids and electrolyte replacement.
* Endocrine: The patient has acromegaly suspected, with a pituitary macroadenoma invading the left cavernous sinus.
* Neuro: The patient has diffuse nerve root enhancement on MRI and is being treated with dexamethasone for malignancy.
* GU: The patient has urinary retention and tender scrotal swelling, which may be related to an enlarged prostate and/or urothelial thickening.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's tachycardia and hypotensive bradycardia may indicate cardiac instability, and he may require further monitoring and treatment.
3. Renal failure: The patient's ARF may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further electrolyte imbalances and potential kidney damage.
4. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of central lines and Foley catheter increase his risk of infection.
5. Malignancy progression: The patient's underlying malignancy may progress, leading to further organ dysfunction and poor outcomes.
6. Hypocalcemia: The patient's hypercalcemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to muscle weakness, cramping, and cardiac arrhythmias.
7. Hypophosphatemia: The patient's hyperphosphatemia may worsen if not properly managed, leading to muscle weakness, cramping, and cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances may worsen if not properly managed, leading to muscle weakness, cramping, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to closely monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with fluids and electrolyte replacement.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte imbalances and adjust treatment as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and take measures to prevent infection.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's malignancy progression and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's pituitary macroadenoma and potential infiltration of surrounding structures.
8. Consider further consultation with endocrinology, neurology, and oncology services to optimize the patient's care.

   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow

   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and
   increased difficulty breathing secondary to copious secretions. Being
   treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant
   process based on chest CT
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
   -Get better COPD history from friend
   -Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
   -Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator
   settings
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure.
   -Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**].
   -EKG
   -Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow
   cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspicion for an
   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high
   given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
   -continue hydration
   -Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry pending
   -touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass
   is possible
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now.
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine consult
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.  Neurosurgery following. Patient already on
   dexamethasone for malignancy treatment.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary. Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although
   in light of recent ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until
   patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc.
   -Continue [**Month/Year (2) 114**] for hospital-acquired PNA. Day 4 vancomycin, Day 3 CTX.

   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to

   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C

   -Foley in place
   -When patient extubated/stabilized and Foley removed, close follow-up

   diagnosis of orchitis. No treatment currently given negative G&C swab.
   -Monitor UOP.

Summary:

The patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and possible lymphoma. He presented with respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode of hypotensive bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. He has a history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention.

Current status:

* Extubated and reintubated due to tachypnea and increased difficulty breathing
* Being treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT
* Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s, TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart failure
* Heme-Onc: Labs trending down and now normal, s/p 2 doses rasburicase, bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow cytometry of peripheral blood pending
* Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving, patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue
* Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly, MRI/MRA shows pituitary macroadenoma (presumptive source)
* Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for possible masses, patient already on dexamethasone for malignancy treatment
* ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc and CTX
* GU: Initial complaint was urinary retention, possibly secondary to enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT
* MSK: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure due to pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis
* Cardiac arrest due to tachycardia and hypotension
* Sepsis due to LLL PNA and possible lymphangitic malignant process
* Renal failure due to ARF and electrolyte imbalance
* Endocrine complications due to acromegaly and possible lymphoma
* Neurological complications due to epidural enhancement and possible masses
* Infectious complications due to Foley and possible urinary tract infection
* Gastrointestinal complications due to tumor lysis syndrome and possible lymphangitic malignant process

Plan:

* Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
* Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
* Get better COPD history from friend
* Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
* Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator settings
* f/u blood cx
* Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**]
* EKG
* Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
* guaiac stool
* f/u Heme/Onc recs
* continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
* continue allopurinol
* EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
* continue hydration
* Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
* daily differential
* BAL flow cytometry pending
* touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass is possible
* monitor BUN and Cr
* continue fluids to CVP 10-12
* avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
* Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
* f/u endocrine consult
* f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
* consider OGTT in future
* ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
* neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of spine not necessary. Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.

Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, hypotensive bradycardia, and suspected tumor lysis syndrome. He has a history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention, and is being worked up for new diagnoses of acromegaly and possible lymphoma.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient was extubated and reintubated due to tachypnea and increased difficulty breathing. He is being treated for LLL PNA and has a suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on chest CT.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is tachycardic, with a heart rate in the 110s/120s. His TSH is within normal limits, and his TTE showed normal EF and no evidence of heart failure.
* Heme-Onc: The patient has significantly elevated LDH, hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperuricemia consistent with tumor lysis syndrome. His labs are trending down and now normal. He has received two doses of rasburicase and is being monitored for further lysis.
* Renal/FEN: The patient has acute renal failure (ARF) that appears to be resolving, with his creatinine back at baseline. He has a Foley catheter in place and is being monitored for electrolyte abnormalities.
* Endocrine: The patient has a new diagnosis of acromegaly, with a pituitary macroadenoma on MRI/MRA. This may explain his initial complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention.
* Neuro: The patient has a spinal epidural enhancement on MRI T-spine that is concerning for possible masses. Neurosurgery is following up on this.
* GU: The patient has a Foley catheter in place and is being monitored for urinary retention. He has a presumptive diagnosis of orchitis and is being followed up for this.
* MSK: The patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias that are likely secondary to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require further intubation and ventilation.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's tachycardia and hypotensive bradycardia may be indicative of cardiac instability.
* Renal failure: The patient's ARF may progress, and he may require further treatment and monitoring.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is at risk for further infection.
* Malignancy progression: The patient's lymphoma or acromegaly may progress, requiring further treatment and monitoring.
* Endocrine complications: The patient's acromegaly may cause further endocrine complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
* Neurological complications: The patient's spinal epidural enhancement may be indicative of a spinal cord compression, which could lead to further neurological complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
* Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
* Get better COPD history from friend
* Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
* Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator settings
* Follow up blood cx
* Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**]
* EKG
* Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
* Guaiac stool
* Follow up Heme/Onc recs
* Continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
* Continue allopurinol
* EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
* Continue hydration
* Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
* Daily differential
* BAL flow cytometry pending
* Touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass is possible
* Monitor BUN and Cr
* Continue fluids to CVP 10-12
* Avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
* Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
* Follow up endocrine consult
* Follow up endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
* Consider OGTT in future
* Ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
* Neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of spine not necessary. Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, with contributions from pneumonia, diffuse bronchovascular disease, lymphangitic engorgement, and possible underlying COPD. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, and the plan is to work towards a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) and possible extubation.
2. Fever: The patient's persistent fever is likely due to an underlying systemic process or infection, and cultures are pending. The patient's fevers will be monitored, and empiric antimicrobials will be continued.
3. Abnormal Bone Marrow: The patient's bone marrow biopsy is unrevealing for a specific diagnosis, with necrosis and small cells of unclear etiology. Further evaluation is planned, including peripheral blood flow cytometry analysis and bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) for flow cytometry.
4. Tachycardia: The patient's tachycardia is likely due to sinus tachycardia with atrial premature complexes (APCs). The patient will be monitored for further evaluation.
5. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sepsis and hypovolemia, and the patient is being managed with vasopressors. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) will be maintained at 10-12 cm H2O.
6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is improving following resuscitation, and it is attributed to acute tubular necrosis (ATN), possible tumor lysis syndrome, bilateral obstruction, and drug effect. The patient's creatinine is now at baseline.
7. Tumor Lysis Syndrome: The patient's tumor lysis syndrome is unclear in etiology, and the patient is being managed with rasburicase and allopurinol. The patient's electrolytes will be trended every 8 hours, and oncology is preliminarily favoring acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
8. Acromegaly: The patient has evidence of pituitary adenoma and is being evaluated further.
9. Nutritional Support: The patient's nutritional support will be initiated, and a total parenteral nutrition (TPN) order will be placed if no procedures are planned.

The patient remains critically ill and will require close monitoring and management of their various medical complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 40-year-old male with a complex medical condition, including tumor lysis syndrome, presumptive lymphoma, and acromegaly. He is currently in the ICU due to respiratory distress, hypotensive bradycardia, and pneumonia.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 38.1°C (100.6°F)
* Heart rate: 116 bpm (108-126 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 147/64 mmHg (118-90 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute (20-27 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%

The patient is intubated and on assist control mode, with a respiratory support device in place. His chest x-ray shows mild pulmonary vascular congestion, new parenchymal opacity at the left lung apex, and worsening opacity at the right lung base.

The patient's laboratory results indicate:

* White blood cell count: 5.5-5.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 7.8-8.9 g/dL
* Platelet count: 140-144 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.5-0.6 mg/dL
* Uric acid: 1.1-1.3 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.8 mmol/L

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Tumor lysis syndrome
* Presumptive lymphoma
* Acromegaly
* Pneumonia
* Respiratory acidosis
* Lactic acidosis
* Hypercalcemia
* Hyperkalemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Hyperuricemia

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continued ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
* Daily chest x-ray
* Obtaining tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal mass
* Continuing allopurinol
* Monitoring lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phosphorus, calcium) daily
* Continuing fluids to CVP 10-12
* Avoiding IV contrast and nephrotoxic medications

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac arrest
* Sepsis
* Acute kidney injury
* Hyperkalemia
* Hyperphosphatemia
* Hyperuricemia
* Lactic acidosis
* Respiratory acidosis
* Pneumonia
* Lymphoma progression

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   40M with tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new diagnoses of
   acromegaly and possible lymphoma, in ICU after respiratory distress
   leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive bradycardia, in the
   setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic acidosis. Original
   presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy and urinary retention.
   Current work-up is considering ALL vs Burkitts.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Extubated and reintubated yesterday due to tachypnea and
   increased difficulty breathing secondary to copious secretions. Being
   treated for LLL PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant
   process based on chest CT
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with fentanyl/midazolam
   -Repeat CXR tomorrow morning
   -Get better COPD history from friend
   -Continue [**Name2 (NI) 114**]
   -Get ABG if change in respiratory status or if change ventilator
   settings
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure.
   -Continue volume resuscitation to goal CVP of [**10-26**].
   -EKG
   -Avoid beta blockers given h/o hypotension on metoprolol
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, flow
   cytometry of peripheral blood now pending with high suspicion for an
   acute lymphoma. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -EBV antibodies pending; consider sending PCR if suspicion is high
   given his hypogammaglobulinemia on SPEP
   -continue hydration
   -Today is Day 4 of dexamethasone. Tomorrow start brief taper.
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry pending
   -touch base with neurosurgery to see if CT guided biopsy of spinal mass
   is possible
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -continue fluids to CVP 10-12
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now.
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine consult
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.  Neurosurgery following. Patient already on
   dexamethasone for malignancy treatment.
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary. Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although
   in light of recent ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until
   patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor
   ID: CXR on [**7-12**] showed LLL PNA, being treated with vanc (since [**7-13**])
   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc.
   -Continue [**Month/Year (2) 114**] for hospital-acquired PNA. Day 4 vancomycin, Day 3 CTX.
   -Increase vanc dosing to 1mg Q8H
   -urine cx negative; sputum and blood cx pending
   -HIV test when patient alert and able to consent
   -EBV antibodies pending
   -Legionella negative
   GU:  Initial complaint was urinary retention. Possibly secondary to
   enlarged prostate from acromegaly and/or urothelial thickening on CT.
   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   -Foley in place
   -When patient extubated/stabilized and Foley removed, close follow-up
   will be needed for h/o urinary retention as well as presumptive
   diagnosis of orchitis. No treatment currently given negative G&C swab.
   -Monitor UOP.
   MSK: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
   -continue pain control with fentanyl

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 40-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress, hypotensive bradycardia, and a history of Bell's Palsy and urinary retention. He has been diagnosed with tumor lysis syndrome, acromegaly, and possible lymphoma. He has undergone bronchoscopy, sputum culture, and EKG, and is currently receiving ventilation and sedation. He has also been treated for LLL PNA, and has undergone chest CT and MRI/MRA.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he requires continued ventilation and sedation. There is a risk of respiratory failure, and the patient may require intubation again.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate underlying cardiovascular disease, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
3. Renal complications: The patient has had acute kidney injury (ARF) and may require further monitoring and treatment to prevent chronic kidney disease.
4. Endocrine complications: The patient's diagnosis of acromegaly may lead to further complications, such as hyperglycemia, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's history of cranial nerve palsies and urinary retention may indicate underlying neurological disease, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Infectious complications: The patient's diagnosis of LLL PNA and possible lymphoma may lead to further infectious complications, such as sepsis or pneumonia.
7. Hematological complications: The patient's diagnosis of tumor lysis syndrome and possible lymphoma may lead to further hematological complications, such as anemia, bleeding, or thrombocytopenia.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of urinary retention and possible orchitis may indicate underlying gastrointestinal disease, and he may require further evaluation and treatment.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation and sedation as necessary.
2. Further evaluate the patient's cardiovascular status and treat any underlying cardiovascular disease.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment as necessary to prevent chronic kidney disease.
4. Continue to manage the patient's endocrine disorders and monitor for any further complications.
5. Evaluate the patient's neurological status and treat any underlying neurological disease.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's infectious status and treat any further infections.
7. Monitor the patient's hematological status and treat any further complications.
8. Evaluate the patient's gastrointestinal status and treat any underlying gastrointestinal disease.

   40M with resolving tumor lysis syndrome, being worked up for new
   diagnoses of presumptive lymphoma and acromegaly, in ICU after
   respiratory distress leading to intubation and one episode hypotensive
   bradycardia, in the setting of pneumonia and respiratory/lactic
   acidosis. Original presenting complaint was Bell
s Palsy, urinary
   retention, and lower extremity weakness.
   Currently trying to obtain tissue for definitive lymphoma diagnosis
   from BAL, peripheral blood, and paraspinal mass.
   By system:
   Respiratory: Intubated, on assist control mode for past 36 hours after
   failed extubation secondary to copious secretions. Being treated for
   PNA, suspicion for infiltrative lymphangitic malignant process based on
   chest CT.
   -Continue ventilation and sedation with propofol/fentanyl/midazolam
   -Wean to pressure support as tolerated.
   -Daily CXR
   -Obtain better COPD history
   -Continue abx for 2 more days (7 day total)
   -Continue ABG twice daily from art line or if changes in respiratory
   status
   -f/u blood cx
   Cardiovascular: Tachycardic to 110s/120s. TSH WNL, TTE showed normal EF
   and no evidence of heart failure. EKG yesterday showed frequent PVCs,
   no signs of myocardial ischemia.
   -Start metoprolol 25mg PO TID and titrate as needed.
   -f/u other cardiology recs
   -transfuse if Hct<21
   -guaiac stool
   Heme-Onc: Labs at admission included significantly elevated LDH,
   hypercalcemia, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia c/w tumor
   lysis syndrome. All trended down and now normal. Now s/p 2 doses
   rasburicase. CT also shows evidence of malignancy
 c/w lymphangitic
   spread of diffuse malignant process, thickening in stomach, ureters.
   Bone marrow biopsy inadequate secondary to necrosis, now trying to
   obtain diagnosis from alternate tissue.
   -f/u Heme/Onc recs
   -continue to trend lysis labs (uric acid, LDH, K, phos, Ca) daily
   -continue allopurinol
   -d/c dexamethasone today
   -daily differential
   -BAL flow cytometry and cytology pending
   -biopsy of paraspinal mass not possible per IR. Plan to repeat bone
   marrow bx on monday
   Renal/FEN: ARF seems to be resolving with Cre back at baseline of 0.5.
   Patient has Foley so h/o urinary retention has not been an issue. This
   will need to be monitored when Foley is eventually removed.
   -monitor BUN and Cr
   -d/c IVF, start again if CVP<8
   -avoid IV contrast, nephrotoxic meds for now
   -Electrolyte abnormalities all improving. Replete as needed
   Endocrine: New diagnosis of acromegaly; MRI/MRA shows pituitary
   macroadenoma (presumptive source). This may help explain initial
   complaints of cranial nerve palsies, LE weakness, and urinary retention
   although follow-up for these complaints will be required when patient
   is extubated and stabilized. Only endocrine lab abnormalities to date
   are an elevated [**Hospital1 **] and LH and a low testosterone. Interestingly, IGF-1
   was normal, although this is not reliable in acute illness. Free IGF-1
   level requested by endocrine was not possible at our lab. Repeat Ca and
   PTH were both normal, eliminating suspicion for parathyroid process.
   -f/u endocrine recs
   -f/u endocrine labs (IGFBP, Vit D)
   -consider OGTT in future
   -ophtho consult for visual fields when patient extubated/alert
   Neuro: MRI T-spine at OSH showed epidural enhancement concerning for
   possible masses.
   -IR to biopsy paraspinal mass
   -neurosurgery has low suspicion for cord compression and repeat MRI of
   spine not necessary.
   -Repeat MRI of pituitary eventually needed although in light of recent
   ARF, this is not a priority and can wait until patient stabilized.
   -better neuro exam as we wean sedation, particularly focused on cranial
   nerve
s V and VII and lower extremity sensation/motor

   and CTX (since [**7-14**]). ID approval was received for vanc. CXR on [**7-15**]

   Tender scrotal swelling also noted on admission and scrotal US
   suggested epididymitis/orchitis. No clear mass was identified and G&C
   swab was negative. [**Month (only) 11**] be related to anasarca and malignancy work-up.
   -Foley in place
   -When patient extubated/stabilized and Foley removed, close follow-up
   will be needed for h/o urinary retention as well as presumptive
   diagnosis of orchitis. No treatment currently given negative G&C swab.
   -Monitor UOP
   MSK: Patient has severe and diffuse arthralgias, most likely secondary
   to hypertrophic arthropathy from acromegaly.
   -avoiding NSAIDs
   -tylenol when awake
